docs.lead_paragraph: Faithful readers know that I've been plagued by arthritic pain in both knees for about a decade and that I've experienced significant symptomatic improvement after daily use of a dietary supplement that combines glucosamine and chondroitin. About six months ago, I also began wearing magnetic knee sleeves when I played tennis and sometimes for my daily three-mile walk. In addition to being a lot more comfortable than those Neoprene knee braces I used to wear, the magnetic sleeves seem to have done more to minimize my discomfort during knee-stressing activities.

headline.main: Less Pain: Is It in the Magnets or the Mind?

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on therapeutic magnets for pain relief; notes that Americans spend more than $300 million a year on magnets, and many of them swear that their pain is relieved; says well-designed, placebo-controlled studies of magnet therapy have been rare, and even researchers who are among leading proponents of magnet theraply concede that larger and better-controlled studies are needed before this approach can rightfully join cadre of alternative therapies that are clearly effective; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors aren't supposed to have favorite patients. But here's a poorly kept secret: we do. Mine was a 57-year-old man named Joe who died recently, after a 15-year battle against AIDS. Although I hadn't been Joe's physician for the several years, since I moved away from the city where he lived, we kept in close contact. Yesterday, I received a letter from his longtime partner, John, telling me that Joe had died from the disease that has shaped our era as starkly as bubonic plague framed the Renaissance. He was, as John put it, brave to his last breath.

headline.main: Those Magic Times When the Patient Makes the Doctor Feel Better

docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Howard Markel on his favorite patient, man who battled AIDS for ten years before dying; says patient changed way he understood adversity cause by illness and importance of having hope and faith, subjects rarely covered in medical school; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For some pregnant women, depression does not always wait to be postpartum. Depression can come at any point in a woman's pregnancy, and if it does, she and her doctor can be in a quandary over whether to try antidepressants. Now researchers believe they may have found a way to help these women without exposing them and their fetuses to drugs. Turning to a technique sometimes used to help people with seasonal affective disorder, the gloom that can settle in as fall comes and the days grow shorter, the doctors have been trying light therapy on their patients.
docs.abstract: Researchers find light therapy has shown promising results in treating pregnant women who are depressed but cannot take antidepressants; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I'm happy for for the couple described in ''The 'Patch' That Saved a Pregnancy'' (Nov. 21), but the account of their experience brings out an important point: if you don't want to risk the safety of a healthy fetus, don't start the prenatal screening process in the first place.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dawn Isbell on Nov 21 article advises against prenatal screeningU

docs.lead_paragraph: A highlight of the carnival season in 17th-century Amsterdam was the public anatomy lesson. Sponsored by the city's Surgeons' Guild, it would draw large crowds to the guild's anatomy theater where the praelector, or public demonstrator, would illustrate his lecture by dissecting a corpse. Often, an artist -- none other than Rembrandt in 1632 and 1656 -- was on hand to paint the praelector and other guild members beside the mutilated cadaver. Today most people would pass on an invitation to witness a human dissection. In the age of body worship fear of the sight of real blood and guts seems stronger than ever, as if only external appearances were now important. Even the many contemporary artists who are again showing interest in the human body usually treat it less as a biological wonder than as a vehicle for human emotions or social commentary.

headline.main: The Human Body in Its Aesthetic Glory and Scientific Gore

docs.abstract: Hayward Gallery in London mounts show, Spectacular Bodies: The Art and Science of the Human Body, From Leonardo to Now, which demonstrates how, since Renaissance, human body has served as bridge between art and science; show includes 300 artistic and medical exhibits; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HELAINE HELMREICH didn't set out to be a novelist. She never had dreams of becoming a writer. Trained as a speech therapist, she had taken a career detour to go into the business of importing linen yarn from China when in 1985, after minor surgery, she found herself hospitalized. Bored, she began reading the romance novels that came to her room via a hospital library cart.

headline.main: Memories Put Down on Paper; 'The Chimney Tree'

docs.lead_paragraph: Ruth Belcher Dyk, one of the last surviving participants in the women's suffrage movement, died in her apartment in Rochester on Nov. 18. She was 99. In a life that included working with delinquent girls, writing three books on psychology and producing anthropological studies of Navajo Indians with her husband, she never lost her fierce commitment to equality.

headline.main: Ruth Dyk, Champion of Women's Suffrage, Dies at 99

docs.abstract: Ruth Belcher Dyk, participant in women's suffrage movement, dies at age 89; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A newborn boy kidnapped from his mother's hospital room was found apparently unharmed, and the police said the woman who took the baby did it because she had faked a pregnancy. Chief Benny Napoleon of the Detroit Police Department said a 20-year-old woman and a man in his mid-20's were arrested on Wednesday night shortly after the baby, Moses Champion, was found at the home of the woman's mother. The police withheld the names of the two people arrested.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Kidnapped Infant Found Safe in Detroit
